thread.title: Woolworths looks to cut ties with Qantas
thread.title_full: Woolworths looks to cut ties with Qantas | afr.com

author: Catie Low and Mark Hawthorne
title: Woolworths looks to cut ties with Qantas
text:
Qantas Frequent Flyer points have been a key selling point of Woolworths Everyday Rewards loyalty program. by Catie Low and Mark Hawthorne Embattled grocery giant Woolworths is looking to axe its relationship with Qantas through its Everyday Rewards card as it wrestles to win back market share from Coles and Aldi.
Sources close to Woolworths suggest the arrangement with Qantas, which means shoppers can earn frequent flyer points when they shop at Woolworths, Big W or BWS is too costly to continue because the retailer has to pay for the points it passes on to customers.
The scheme is a major selling point for Woolworths at at time when Australia's biggest supermarket is struggling to rebuild its image as a competitive alternative to Aldi and Coles.
The relationship with Qantas is one of the key parts of the Woolworths' rewards program, which was launched in 2007.
Woolworths and BWS shoppers earn 1 frequent flyer point for every dollar they spend over $30 in one transaction when they scan their orange Everyday Rewards card at the till. At Big W consumers can earn 1 frequent flyer point for every $2 spent over $30 in a single transaction.
A spokeswoman from Woolworths said the supermarket had previously indicated that it planed to "make changes" to the Everyday Rewards program "to benefit our loyal customers."
She said more information would become available in coming weeks.
Woolworths revealed its plans to review its rewards program at an investor strategy day earlier this year.
 It's understood all options are on the table, including cutting key relationships such as Qantas, according to sources close to the retailer.
"I don't think anyone thinks Qantas is cheap, Qantas makes a fair bit of money out of its rewards program," the source said.
Woolworths will report its first quarter sales next week and analyst Deutsche Bank is forecasting a decline in food and liquor sales of 0.5 per cent compared to forecast 3.1 per cent comparable food and liquor sales at Coles over the same period.
A spokesman for Qantas said it had been in discussions with Woolworths over the details of the loyalty program "to ensure it continues to meet the needs of our Frequent Flyers."
